theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on accumulation of late-acting deleterious germline mutations due to declining natural selection with age.
Describes accumulation of age-specific deleterious germline mutations driven by weakening selection pressure at older ages.
Emphasizes age-specific effects of spontaneous germline mutations on mortality and declining selection intensity with age.
Posits accumulation of late-acting deleterious alleles in germline due to declining force of natural selection with age.
Focuses on declining age-specific natural selection allowing germline mutation accumulation and antagonistic pleiotropy.
Describes accumulation of latent disease susceptibilities via natural non-selection acting on germline mutations expressed late in life.
Evolutionary genetic theory highlighting accumulation of late-acting deleterious germline alleles due to declining selection.
Medawar’s hypothesis on declining purifying selection with age leading to accumulation of deleterious germline mutations.
Mutation accumulation theory emphasizing accumulation of late-acting deleterious germline mutations and increased heritability with age.
Genetic load theory describing accumulation of late-acting deleterious germline mutations affecting longevity under hazard-adjusted selection.
Nearly neutral theory focusing on fixation of slightly deleterious germline mutations influenced by population size and life-history traits.
Non-programmed aging theory emphasizing aging as a by-product of accumulated germline mutations and declining selection with age.
Focuses on energy allocation trade-offs between reproduction and somatic maintenance shaping aging via disposable soma model.
Describes how longevity influences cooperative breeding evolution via life-history trade-offs affecting reproduction and survival.
Explores extrinsic mortality effects on life-history evolution, reproductive senescence, and post-reproductive lifespan as non-adaptive byproduct.
Evolutionary senescence theory linking declining natural selection, antagonistic pleiotropy, and environmental hazards shaping aging rates.
Condition-dependent mortality theory showing how survival-reproduction trade-offs and sex-specific reproductive senescence arise from extrinsic mortality.
Natural selection via differential survival theory emphasizing how survival patterns shape senescence manifestation within populations.
Evolutionarily conserved senescence theory linking extrinsic mortality, gene expression changes, and life-history trade-offs in aging.
Race for replication hypothesis relating mitochondrial genome size and replication efficiency to life-history and metabolic trade-offs.
Focuses on accumulation of somatic mutations causing genome instability and cellular dysfunction driving aging.
Describes accumulation and tolerance limits of somatic mutations in proliferative and non-proliferative tissues contributing to aging.
Details tissue-specific somatic mutation accumulation, somatic selection, and links to aging and disease risk.
Two-level evolutionary conflict theory in plants focusing on somatic mutations with conflicting effects at branch and whole-organism levels.
